author: {'steamid': '76561199058827599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1681350930}
review:
So I played 3 hrs. I just wanted to learn how to do the basics, like fight, loot, and gather. Ended up spending all of my in game $$ on tools for gathering. Fought a bit. I thought that all seemed reasonable, or a reasonable way to do it.

Looked up a Youtube to figure out how to do more.

Accepted all the tasks. Clicked on some different skills, switched between them to try some things. Then felt like I was at a stopping point. 

Because I wanted to figure out how to do the first task, poaching fish, but that requires cooking... so, a stove (?) But I can't get a stove or eggs because I have no in game $. 

Also my inventory is full, my shop is full, my boo-chest is upgraded 1x and I don't know what to do with most of what I have. Am I supposed to trash 75% of it and fight more?   

I love the gameplay itself, the style, the concepts, but already it just feels odd, and I've felt a bit lost the whole time.  The biggest complaint I've read is about there not being many people on there, so maybe the game would run a ton more smoothly if there were more people, because we could share stuff? Trade? Sell? 

The theme seems to be that people can help each other fight, and can exchange/sell each other goods and join guilds together. But, all of those things seem to have huge roadblocks.

I think that conceptually it would be cool to see other's boo's, friends, guildmembers, or anyone's? I feel like that is part of the game but on empty servers I don't really know.

******I'd definitely recommend putting everyone on the same server if there's a lack of people in the game, and reducing anything limiting the use of merchant areas, guilds, newspaper ads, just to liven the place up and get stashes moving.*******

 I mean it's called stash, not trash, and I know all I'm going to be doing if I go back on is tossing almost everything with very little understanding of what I'm throwing out. And since I'm kinda not going to want to do that, I'll be hard pressed to play more. 

It's like you really need certain items, but have no idea how to actually get them(?) I guess the gist is to toss everything else out and keep fighting to open chests. Which I know is an aspect, but I don't feel like that was the original intent (?) With the main intent being helping one another and having player shops? Maybe I'm wrong. 
What do I know,  I can't even boil an egg *shrug*

P.S. Yes, I did find the help screen, and the wiki, and some youtubes. And yes, I thought I was doing well learning how to get around and fight and gather, but maybe throw newbs a bone and put an optional tutorial with a few simple beginning tasks and achievements like to learn in an interactive style how to learn a skill, make a recipe, utilize the different parts of your boo and HUD. Just so some of us don't feel so lost.

Do I recommend this game? Well, I'm going to say yes, because the main complaint is that there just aren't enough people on it, and it hasn't made me mad... just kind of stuck me lost at what feels like a stopping point very quickly. So, if people are cool with that, let um come in! I hope that they take the advice of making the interactive things easier to use: Like the guild and different shops and a bit more interactive tutorial just to let people feel like they are getting somewhere, doing something, and partaking in a shared game.

Update: Invited a friend in, to try to play together, thinking that fighting monsters with him would be fun, however nope. We couldn't enter into any fighting or harvesting areas together. I'm uninstalling and not recommending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198225732032', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1545239432}
review:
[b](All the numbers here I got from [url=https://steamdb.info/app/466660/graphs/]SteamDB[/url] - I'm making this review cause I love thinking numbers and I just figured I'd share cause this is a bit odd to me. Just take everything I say here with a grain of salt lol)[/b]

I don't think I've seen a more chaotic playerbase trend than with [i]Stash[/i] (might be an exaggeration but whatevs). Ever since it released, the player count for this game didn't break triple digits all that often. Rewind to a little over a year ago though, and all of a sudden this game has over 8k players in it [i](keep in mind that this hasn't been updated since 2018)[/i]. After that it dips back to just above 500 before going to 10k just two weeks after the dip. The highest count recorded is 32,094 people on March 17 2022. As of this review's posting, the count is 23,171.

Before anyone starts thinking "oh someone's probably botting this thing," I say two things in response:

[list]
   [*]I don't know why anyone would even bother botting a pretty much dead game in the first place.
   [*]The player count over the hours is a bit rigid for it to be botting in my opinion.
[/list]

The current player count has stayed like single digits around 23,171 for hours now. If it were bots, then I would think that count would drop en masse as they go down for a period of time - also it would be a bit confusing that bots would only come up every so often instead of being persistent.

I just thought I'd write this "review" cause it seemed a bit odd to me that a game that's been effectively neglected all of a sudden has like 20k people playing it lol. (Also I'm writing this at like midnight and my eyes are quickly wanting to seal themselves shut so maybe I got sidetracked? Idk though lol)

But meh, what do I know - I'm just some random guy on the webs of the internet just saying what comes to mind :P

... oh ye and the game's not that great tbh

author: {'steamid': '76561198044838472', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 15042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15042, 'last_played': 1510619904}
review:
Hey there.
Since I'm cleaning up my gargantuan Steam library, I stumbled upon Stash. I fuzzily remember my times in Stash, but for example I do remember that at some time I could get qualified for being a helper. Won't write down the name, as I got stalked by very weird players back then.

After trying to remember what happened and why I stopped playing, I remembered. Fuzzy stuff in their Discord and horrible stuff outside, which I mentioned: stalking.
Anyhow, the game in the meanwhile got less and less interesting to play. Why? Because no feedback was actually being followed. Frogdice apparently moved on from this dumpster on fire that ONCE was a promising game.

Should you play this? As an avid player of abandonware and old games, even I can't suggest anything positive about this game. I think at some point this game had a POINT, but it got lost very quickly and whoever is behind the development is highly temperamental. I do remember a lot of discussions about this particular aspect.

Turn based MMOs are still interesting, so try some other. This one has literally NOTHING to offer, outside from maybe, one day, someone who will get this bag of lost hope up and maybe relaunch the game with bugs fixed and a decent state of mind.

P.S. the developer is doing some super shady stuff with player count. This was reported to Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167257205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1609528064}
review:
Ci ho giocato un po', e per ora non credo che ripeterò l'esperienza.
E' un gioco molto semplice e lento, un sandbox a turni che ricorda quando da piccoli giocavamo ad hero quest e dovevamo lavorare parecchio di fantasia :)
Che dire: secondo me è bello, ma non è stato fortunato.
Non so perché la community si sia persa per strada, ma sembra un gioco deserto, lasciato a se stesso, non so neanche se c'è dello staff attivo.
Quando giochi la sensazione, oltre alla quasi inquietante solitudine, è che il gioco sia un pochino ripetitivo.
Ho notato che ci sono parecchie possibilità, ma onestamente non le ho provate, se avete voglia di iniziare vi consiglierei di farlo in 4 o 5 in maniera goliardica e vedere se lo staff risponde all'attività.
Questi giochi hanno bisogno di essere guidati perché lasciati a se stessi come questo sono piuttosto noiosi.

In totale: se non sapete cosa fare e volete cimentarvi nel riportarlo in vita fate pure, ma credo che sia morto...
...da un po'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198335230121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7496, 'last_played': 1609391652}
review:
It's been over three years. The models for town NPCs still haven't been placed, requiring players to interact with placeholders to access their functions. Due to the table top motif of the game these would be static models, so there isn't even any animation that needs to be done. Three years, and counting.

How could a game that receives so little time and effort devoted to it by the developer possibly be worth the time you'd have to invest to get anywhere playing it, considering the heavy cost the grind factor would demand. Why would you expect anything better to look to going forward?

In my opinion, it isn't worth your valuable time now and there is no reason to expect it will be any time soon, if ever. You'd be better off spending your time elsewhere.

Not recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037514594', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 8432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8040, 'last_played': 1608423240}
review:
This game is dead. The only people you will ever see are new players who will quit before level 10. The games economy requires players, and since there are none you will have to do everything by yourself. The game is not balanced for solo play. On top of this there's a trash xp debt system making it extremely difficult to level if you ever die. You can build up more xp debt than is required for you to level up. The game has not been improved on in any way since release. I am a founder and I regret spending even a dime on this game.

The developers are toxic trash that take any feedback and disregard it entirely, hence why their trash game is dead to begin with. This company Frogdice is filled with egotistical scammers who made this game as a cash grab forcing people to pay for overpriced cosmetics to have any change in their appearances, or spend tons of money buying bags to store items in their inventory.

Let this game disappear forever, and never support any game they ever make in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033432058', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 869, 'last_played': 1601737549}
review:
First off I'd like to say that this game looks very interesting in that it tries to look like a tabletop game with character minatures placed on the map and battle areas, which is pretty unique.

But that is really everything positive I can say about this game I'm sad to say.

There is no real tutorial, you're pretty much dropped into the world and got to find out how things work on your own (untill you figure out there's a "manual" you can get some hints from)
The game is free to play, so you know there's cash grabs going on like a $60 "founders pack" and cosmetic stuff for your base.

Biggest issue...? Where the heck are the players? When I first started I would see one or two in the startign area, but they might as well have been bots as i've had no social interaction. I skip a few months and check back just now and everything is dead. No players to be seen, no auctions going on, nothing.... Sure you could play this solo if you don't mind always being at a disadvantage in fights, but it's probably not going to be much fun, or you might be able to bribe some friends to play it with you.

I can't recommend this game right now, unless players return perhaps but that seems unlikely.
At least it's free if you decide to check it out anyways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117834951', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1637037243}
review: This game has few players true, and for a game that touts loot theres not much to do with it but sell it to vendors, but if you like turn base strategy and dont mind making alts for crafting stuff and only being able to log in/out trade with alts with one item at a time. Then its a nice relaxing game. theres no way to do higher level stuff im guessing as there is no one to party with.. but if you need to wind down with something that feels rpgish with no real goal but to fight lower level dungeons... which is kinda my thing..i guess this is a mixed review..some would like it others would not

author: {'steamid': '76561198026561587', 'num_games_owned': 30, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 223, 'last_played': 1591129055}
review:
This has been in my games list for a while, decided i might play it to see if it is a game I remember playing or would like to play.  Oh needs a secondary log in,   Annoying as STEAM credentials should all be that is needed for any game on steam but whatever,

Create a new account, put in an email address and other info ... email already used.  Huh, are you sure?  ok, go through the process of resetting password ... no reply to my email.

Try a 2nd email address, same deal.  Try a 3rd email address that I have not used in 6+ years, let alone for any games ... email already used.

If a company **requires** you to have a secondary log in, independent of steam, have the F'ing decency to have the game system able to open new accounts, reply to pass reset requests, and have a database that is accurate with actual used email addresses.

That 3.7 hours?  It was me trying, on and off, to get an account started / verified / password reset in between youtube vids.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025174481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1511748065}
review:
While the art is very attractive and I like the style of playing a miniature moving around the world map, I just cannot recommend this game for a number of reasons.

One is that it is a boring slog.  Moving from place to place takes forever.  Just moving around the town to get to merchants can involve vast distances, which is really boring with the click to move stuff.

Another is that the dungeons are very frustrating.  You quickly fill up your inventory, but then cannot just leave the dungeon because monsters have respawned behind you, forcing you to fight them again.  Now you have to spend time sorting inventory and throwing away what you want the least.

Gathering is annoying.  Crafting is grindy.  You are basically forced to have multiple characters to craft, but then transferring anything between them or storing your materials is going to require real money being spent due to the extreme limitations placed by the game.

I really wanted to like this game, but the game failed me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031261101', 'num_games_owned': 2322, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 2249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2249, 'last_played': 1577350356}
review:
This is a game that was clearly abandoned not only before most of its planned content was added, but before very early Early Access features like basic balancing, basic interface polishing, and basic information feedback were added. In short, it struck me as being a complete trainwreck.

I found the gameplay unpleasantly dull and underdeveloped, with absolutely nothing that stood out for mention, much less compliment. I didn't see any indication of other players being online, and there are countless indications online that the game community is long dead and that the game stopped being updated a long while back. 

 The game feels like someone took out the most tedious, underdeveloped elements of Runescape and Everquest, sparsely dabbed a bit of the resulting mixture onto a very bare-bones, flash-game-style framework and then slapped a decidedly poor, unresponsive, information-lacking user interface on top of things, all just before promptly deciding that developing games was simply too much effort and dropping the project completely. 

Maybe some elements get fleshed out later, I can't say I managed to get too far into the game (or, more accurately, I couldn't tolerate playing any more than I did), but what I played was user-unfriendly, boring, grindy, clunky, unresponsive, unintuitive, poorly explained, and just so decidedly unfun that I'm rather confident the game never manages to get even a little bit bearable later in. 

To support that perspective, every comment I've seen that goes into the later game actually describes it as being even MORE underdeveloped and unbearable than the early game. Honestly, I've got to wonder if the positive reviews for this game were arranged by the publisher, or posted off an Early Access mindset: "Well, it's gotta be able to get better than THIS, right? Let's just post a positive review to encourage them! Now to drink the other half of this bottle of bourbon.. hey, I was reviewing a survival game, right? ..It's Steam, I must have been."

..I have only just become aware that I may perhaps have some rather peculiar perspectives towards Early Access gamers. >.>

And yeah, Steam misreported my gametime even worse than usual. I think I managed about an hour and a half of play all told, before I remembered that engaging in masochism doesn't result in you getting a free pony. Whoops.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025635047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 27442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27442, 'last_played': 1574046815}
review:
Stash is pretty much a ghost town now. It was never really complete enough to take it out of Early Access. I backed it on Kickstarter, and I really wanted to like it. Much of what was touted during the Kickstarter campaign never materialized. The game does have some interesting ideas. The crafting system could have been fun, but fatal flaws in the resource gathering mechanism and in the tedious system for buying and selling crafted items made it impossible to sustain a workable player economy. Combat became uninteresting. The in-game transactions are too pricey; I wonder whether this may have actually prevented adequate monetization to support continued development.

I took a break for a while. When I came back to check on progress, the formerly active developers and player community were gone. The developers advised players to use their official forums, Discord, and wiki instead of using the Steam community, but there is nothing useful happening there anymore either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198130744700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1559977644}
review:
So, I'll make it short:

The community is nearly dead, and leveling is extremely difficult the smaller party that you are in. It is a huge grind in order to level up anything in your base, but it mainly requires you to fight some monsters. 

The community, however, is not nonexistent. What is left of this game, which is meant to be social and uses Hay Day-like market systems, is still worth at least a try. There is a small community left alive, and they are all accepting and helpful. On my first day playing, I was invited into a party of four people, two of us being newcomers. Even though we set the looting type to "free grab" instead of random distribution, everyone communicated well, and got what they needed. 

All in all, while the game may be dead, I had a pretty great first impression.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041867750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1525390417}
review:
The game feels overall like a survival of a lost on an island without a chance of return, but isn't that a good point. You have to cope with loneliness, endless grinding, other harsh conditions described shortly in average thumb-down reviews. But that shouldn't be a problem for a hard-core grinder, if you are one.

The game gives you all to succeed and prosper without the need of P2W, plus based on the developer's history it is going to be kept on 24/7 for the next 20 years.

Even there is much more to add in the game development, and frankly negative reviews should be considered before playing this as they emphasize the fact the game has special taste and is not for any and every player, I will give this positive review by enlightening as many good points the game has as I can describe.

First good point: This game does effectively NOT require Steam to play! Yay, you can forget the Steam curse in the background! I play this for a year and only have 6.5 hours logged as Steam! Really good point for laptops as you can save more PC memory, I play from a 10 yo laptop and the game minimum settings combined with no need for Steam client allow smooth 3D performance even on such kinda PC.

Point 2: It's a sandbox IMO. Even there is not much population, you can grab your world to the very last thing and control it, much like you do in Minecraft. You start from literally, zero. Six crafts to master, so you can craft everything starting from your own workbench and ending on enchanting your hand made gear. YOU craft your whole gameplay.

3: Grinding. It's a good, very good time killer. Up to 5 minutes per turn based combat, if you need to go AFK, your combat can last for hours or you can finish it in a minute if you play faster. You can master what, how you grind and where you grind. If you need cash you go kill skeletons, if you need seeds you go kill chompy plants. You know where are those dungeons and how to get there. Only given you find it out yourself. Experience matters.

4: You can try ironman as you can avoid or flee a battle you feel you gonna lose. Or you can die easily if you start playing careless. There is deaths counter, every other counters, statistics on everything. You remember exactly why you lost that fight. Make your own clan (much like your family) not a guild, be your own boss. If you lucky having clan mates you can grow it. Or play alone and enjoy your own clan shop.

5: Up to 50 alts per one account! Store all your loot, open shops and manage farmlands and crops for your cooking, transfer goods to main via shared slots. No players online? My army of alts laughs at this. I am too busy to notice.

P.s. I'm not giving the review to promote the game, just feel that this lacks pointed out review it deserves, based not only on first impression of legions of quitters I see coming and quitting. If you grind this you will get how to enjoy this. If this fits YOU, I repeat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198804554605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1537800032}
review:
[b]Horrible interface & irritating registration system.[/b]

[i]So, I took my time & filled in everything for account registration. Since my last name uses a letter that's not in the English alphabet the game wont allow it & so, I was trying to figure a way around that. But, apperantly if I take more than 5 minutes I get disconnected (I wasn't even connected anywere, I had the registration window opened, nothing else) & so I had to rewrite everything again. Then I registered, logged in & the game enforced me to check my email... Well, I gave up at this point.[/i]

As they say, first impression is everything. The graphics from the trailer seem great but the interface is horrible, it feels like this game was made in the 90s. I have not played the game itself but I doubt it's anywhere near decent.
developer_response:
Would you consider emailing us so we can help you?

stash@frogdice.com

Your situation sounds very unique and something our small team would never have predicted.

review: A great little gem of a game.  It has just about everything needed to be successful, except a playerbase.  It has one, just not of any large quantity.  That being said, the devs are almost always in game standing right outside the city to answer any questions you may have, all while keeping the community free toxic behaviors.   So, give it a shot.  It's free, will take you less than 5 minutes to download and you may find that although not 'flashy' and action packed, not every game has to be in order to be good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198183482579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1534289452}
review:
Finally! A game with no tutorials that treats me like a warrior or an animal instead of a retarded idiot who can not move its own fucking avatar without an anoying NPC telling him how to play.
I missed games like these where you had to experiment instead of being pulled and forced to do stuff you do not want to.

On the other hand, there are a few pet peeves i had:
1.- Costumes are very basic, they are just Body + helmet + handhelds... this was OK in 2007. But eleven years later it is just disappointing... I would love to wear different gauntlets with the armor i have or let my driad sorceress wear sandals instead of boots
2.- Microtransactions, they are not bad in a free to play game like this, but asking for them to change the size of your base is a bit anoying
3.- Gibberish english that would make hornstown blush. Grammar errors are everywhere and it makes hard to understand what is happening. I know my english is not perfect but... seriously. this game is full of "all your base are belong to us" sentences.
4.- Trope-ish MMORPG quests that involve junk collecting, plague cleaning and grinding. We have seen these before in the other 12341029346781 clones of Ragnarok/WoW. Is asking for something different this time too much?

Besides that, this is a must if you like old school MMORPGs

author: {'steamid': '76561197983193341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1531683548}
review: Game did not know my steam account. Made me make yet another account.
developer_response:
As noted in the description of the game:

----------
NOTE: As is very common for MMORPGs, you will have to create an account to play. You do not login with your Steam account. That is the only way we can provide full support for our customers.
----------

I feel like this is not the sort of thing a game deserves a negative review for since this is the typical way the vast majority of MMORPGs work.

Plus, the game is free. You can immediately see this and decide not to waste any time if you don't want to make an account.

author: {'steamid': '76561198845032782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1530832284}
review: Stash has been a fun game that I've been able to enjoy both casually and more seriously. It's fun trying to work out the most efficient combinations in the turn-based combat system. Each class definitely has its own perks. Give it a try if you like tactical turn-based gaming. There's also a great community building up around it to share the experience with.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002488207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1522, 'last_played': 1530315753}
review:
Stash starts off feeling very much like the good old days of RPGs, when you were sort of thrown into the pool and had to figure out how to swim without a detailed tutorial. This doesn't last long, however, because you begin to find a rhythm in the first couple hours. The turn-based tactical combat reveals its complexity bit by bit the more you play, and creating that self-inflicted challenge by putting yourself in difficult scenarios is a big part of the fun.

It can be a bit of a grind at times, sure, but the point of a grind (for me) is always about the quality of the loot. And the loot is here. Finishing off a dungeon can be outrageously rewarding if you get something special. The experience (not the gameplay, which is quite different) reminds me a bit of those hours I used to spend grinding it out in Diablo. You live for those teeth-grinding moments when the loot is just right.

The community is on the smaller side, but those who are active are helpful and friendly. In all honesty, I'd rather dig into a game with a smaller playerbase with more interactions, than a massive social hub where you don't really know anyone. Again, this game is best enjoyed when pushing yourself just a little bit more, just a little further.... To try just another dungeon.

If you like the grind, you like loot, you like a tight community, then just give Stash a couple hours of your time. There's literally nothing to lose, so see if it's right for you.

It was right for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198844624854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 95, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1530212331}

author: {'steamid': '76561198093528613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 337225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275748, 'last_played': 1544221023}
review:
This game wasn't what I expected when I first found it. Grid map, turn based...a healthy dose of dungeons and dragons without the prep time. Choose from classic classes like warrior, healer, hunter, and elementalist. Early game is pretty basic, but since you get a new skill every level that changes quickly.

The most important thing to most people looking for a quality free to play title on Steam is that there is absolutely no pay gate. Nothing you can't earn with in game currency.

The Dev's and community are stellar. Active discord and very quick responses.

However this game is an old school grind. If you don't dig a grind Stash isn't for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033891721', 'num_games_owned': 662, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3810, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3766, 'last_played': 1533897009}
review:
This game is unbelievably dry. There's a serviceable tactical combat system but strategy and positioning don't really seem that important. You can pin an enemy between yourself and a piece of terrain and that reduces their damage. You can flank and surround enemies also. But even with all this, it's just rudimentary tactics. It doesn't really do much to excite me. Also, the special abilities and spells are functional but not exciting.

The stash in camp starts with 20 slots for your character and 1 slot shared with your characters. It costs 7000 Medallions to add ONE slot to the shared stash. Adding a slot to your individual character's stash is also one slot at a time but you can use in game materials and Triads, the money that drops from monsters and shopkeepers. Everything is similarly monetized, "do you want more than ONE crafting skill per character?" "That will be 5000 Medallions please." The coins are priced at this moment at 4000 Medallions for $5 USD. These space upgrades and character upgrades seem to be too expensive. Giving a character just one crafting skill seems to be a little too strict.

The reason why I make such a big deal about the stash is that the game throws TONS of crafting materials and items at you. Many items need to be refined with machines that you can place in your BOO. That's right, your camp is actually called a "BOO" in game. This stands for "Base of Operations." Upgrading your BOO from just a sleeping roll, tiny chest and a cart is very expensive and basically the goal of the game. If you do not upgrade your BOO, there's no space to place the crafting stations or refiners that you need to use the raw materials. I'm surprised that none of these crafting stations exists in town, I suppose everyone crafts in secret in this world while hiding in their basements. 

Let's say that you just want to sell the items and move on. Well, there's no easy way to sell them. You can rent a stall in town or add the items to your stall in camp. I added several items to my stall in camp and nothing sold. You have to advertise what you are selling my marking it individually with an AD icon. First one is free, but then you have to pay unless you want to wait. It is also free to take an item down, but after that you have to pay or wait. Of course the stalls in town cost money, your choice of medallions or Triads with various rental periods. The next issue I had with selling was that the populations is so small that the player driven economy doesn't really exist. Prices seem to fluctuate wildly and other players, and their stalls, are the only method to do a price check.

I purchased the bundles from Chrono.gg and Otakubundle and they provided me with premium convenience items and 2 mounts. I found the mounts were underwhelming as they are just pieces of gear you equip and never see. I'm supposed to use my imagination I suppose, which is something I am capable of as I was playing Original Dungeons and Dragons before many of you were born. Even with XP Boost potions and some upgrades, I didn't feel like the money was well spent. I ended up using my currency on a bag slot and a larger bag to carry around with my starting backpack. It wasn't a very exciting purchase.

I ended up starting my first character over because I realized that male magic users, the Elementalists, NEVER wear a shirt. There's a costume system that covers your gear and locks you into your starting character's appearance. It looks like it changes in increments of 5{?} 10{?} levels with crafted costumes that you can wear. There was only two costumes available in the Medallion shop per class and the Elementalist ones were fancy but still shirtless. I asked other players and they basically told me "I chose the no shirt life." That's when I decided to start a new character.

When I made my new character, I had to juggle my account bound items from my old character one at a time using the one slot shared stash. Eventually my wife took pity on me and made an account and a character and she helped me move my remaining possessions. The shared space is SO small, it's hard to accept. This is especially a problem considering that you can only learn one crafting  skill per character and you need to juggle materials between them. Obviously many of these problems can be mitigated by guild mates but the population of the game is very low. As of this moment, the population is very low. [url=https://steamcharts.com/app/466660] Here is a link to the Steam Chart for Stash.[/url]

Another interesting feature is that the creator of the game has a character and is parked right next to the only city in the game at all hours of the day. He is denoted as staff by the lilypad next to his name. He spams the entire screen with advertisements for events and special equipment packs. He's obviously very devoted. If you complain about the game, in game, you will face the game creator and his minions. The ultimate boss battle! I'm half heartedly joking here, but it is kind of true.

Overall this game can be best described as a stale lemon cookie. At one time it was delicious, but now it's difficult to eat and the chef still insists on selling it to you for full price. I'm going to try and put some more time into the game and talk to the veteran players to get an idea of anything I missed or misunderstood. This review many be subject to change, but for now it is a thumbs down.

EDIT:

I purchased a $50 Limited Stash pack and really gave the game a good try after this review. The pack gave me a full suit of purple armor and recreated my elementalist and got him some levels with a shirt on. I'm staying with a thumbs down. I feel that I wasted my money and time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201326962', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 414, 'last_played': 1529974909}
review:
Una lástima este juego, porque se le ve potencial para ser entretenido.
Pero en general, el juego es tan lento (tanto en el juego en sí como navegar por la interfaz) y falto de emoción (música sosa y olvidable, poca variedad de enemigos) que se vuelve tedioso seguir jugando.
Eso sí, si esto no supone una pega para ti, la gente es muy maja y da buen rollo en general, cosa que no se puede decir de muchos MMOs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001241298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1529899572}
review:
Where should I start?

I cannot, in good conscience, call this product a game and will therefore refuse to do so, it shall be referred to simply as the "product". As such, I cannot recommend this product to anyone. 

This heap of drudge is so dull in fact, it wouldn't even cut warm butter. It is so uninventive, you can write up a better game design document by having your dog roll over a few keyboards laid out on the floor. It is so unimaginative, there's more to tell about a spilled glass of water. It is so disengaging, you'll have to reconsider your personal definition of boring. It is so indigestive, your wallet should suffer from constipation of money. The tactical combat is so shallow, Match 4 is more challenging than this.

But of course, this product is focused on microtransactions.

This board simply has been folded wrong. Yet, the dev commenting here can get really edgy if they don't like your review, and I bet they'd rather delete them all.

I wish I could get a refund for the time spent to see for myself, that this product is what the other reviews think it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042150253', 'num_games_owned': 759, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1530497549}
review:
I decided to start playing this game with a friend, and honestly I really didn't expect I'd like it very much. It turned out to be a charming game though, its early game combat lacks a bit depth, but I expect, and have been told, it gets more strategically challenging later on. The UI & controls feel pretty clean aswell. There are plenty of shortcuts for actions you can take in game, and all the menuing is pretty straight forward. But if there's anything I really must touch on about this game, its the developer.

The support this developer gives to his players is simply amazing, and he actually cares about the community hes growing. I had contacted support regarding an issue ingame, and they were incredibly friendly, prompt, and thorough with their responses. By far the best customer support expereience I've had in any game thus far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017962506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1712, 'last_played': 1530556189}
review:
I've only been playing this game for a short while but so far I like what I see. The combat is simple, the UI is basic and easy to use, and I've been enjoying playing with my friend so far.
The shining gem of our experience so far has been support from the developer regarding redeeming a code for an ingame bundle. I purchased two of said codes and elegantly broke one of them (because I'm an idiot, gotta represent), and the developer was extremely helpful and friendly in resolving the situation, going out of his way to get us the items I purchased.
Overall I'm enjoying the game and impressed with the developer, would recommend at least giving it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102375505', 'num_games_owned': 397, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1531582811}
review:
So far i've have been enjoying this game with my kids. even bought the Chrono sale for 5 bucks. Its an easy to play laid back RPG style MMO and we can play it on some out dated computers so it's a thumbs up for us! Def worth trying out.

Ok I got some sleep and ready to add more to this lol... It's easy to play, easy to learn, free to play and a game I can play with my kids. We ended up playing pass 3am so yeah it's fun lol. The only thing I dont like is that there isn't a tutorial. It may be kinda hard for someone who is new to the RPG/MMO gaming. Overall tho its a fun game to try out specially if you are lookin to game with the kids.


*update*
I'm giving this a thumbs down due to the fact that i spent money on this game and never got all the items... Asked in game and I wasn't the only one. I filed a ticket and it took them OVER A WEEK to reply... This isn't a game with over million ppl playing so waiting that long is BS. This is the trash they sent back to me.

A customer support staff member has replied to your support request, #116664 with the following response: 
---------------------------------------- 

Is this still a problem? Have you received what was expected? 

---------------------------------------- 
We hope this response has sufficiently answered your questions. If not, please do not send another email. Instead, reply to this email or login to your account for a complete archive of all your support requests and responses. 


Really?! Isn't it your job to look into my account and see if I got my items? I have to wait over a week to hear from them and instead of getting help I get a jackass question! Oh it's been like 3 weeks or so since I bought that package and I STILL HAVEN'T GOT ALL MY ITEMS. I'm done giving these people my money and most likely done playing this game...

author: {'steamid': '76561198035861365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1529819959}
review:
To be fair, so far its been pretty fun.
It develops super slow however and getting things to work with a friend isn't exactly the easiest.
On top of that, the mods hound you about your name of all things.
YOUR NAME.
You have to name your character something that fits 'fantasy style lore.'
You have to have a name fit for roleplay or you can lose your character.
Personal customization is a large part of RPGs, and this is just ridiculous.
Most likely will not be playing more.
developer_response:
This player had a character named "Notaniggr". 

Our name rules are clearly displayed during creation and this very clearly and obviously was a violation. The person was asked politely to remake with an appropriate name.

> > To be fair, so far its been pretty fun.

So the game is fun, but we get a negative review because you aren't allowed to be "Notaniggr".... Seriously?

author: {'steamid': '76561197998391180', 'num_games_owned': 3439, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1518307591}
review: Honestly, the developer is a pretty cool dude. If you enjoy a fantasy setting as much as I do there is really no reason not to give Stash a try. There is a lack of tutorial so you might need to do some YouTube research before attempting. Overall a nice f2p title that could see a good amount of success if the barrier for entry was lowered just a little bit. Give it a try, see what it's about... There's honestly nothing to lose.

author: {'steamid': '76561198190281225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1859, 'last_played': 1608057202}

author: {'steamid': '76561198050501737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3790, 'last_played': 1530213762}
review:
Fairly new to the game and I will be the first to say there are issues that need to be addressed;

-no clear backstory or overall goal to draw players into the game
-a lackluster economy that really benefits nobody but the post level 15 characters
-a bit too much grinding early on. In my mind you need to be able hook the player before you introduce them to treadmill (and boy does this game have a treadmill)
-the tutorial needs some serious work. As it is now you could wander around forever and unless you happen to ask the right questions at time when the right people (you know, the helpful ones) you could wind up boring yourself to death in a few short hours.

But despite all of these drawbacks it does seem to have a pretty good community in place and the game has a fair amount of potential. If the issues suggested above are addressed then their is no telling what the ceiling could be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005500338', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1529298771}
review:
Made a character, tutorial tells me to go to the dungeon, got there and got pummeled by the first encounter 7 times in front of the dungeon. All enemies have 80HP, you hit between 20-25 most encounter have between 3-7 enemies. Garbage game. 

EDIT: After trying again and going inside the first dungeon which is the mines recommended level is 1-3, alright, get in first encounter, Goblins and Goblin mages, died. Next try, same story but with Slime cubes. Third time's the charm right? Nope. "use of terrain" Doesn't matter at all when there's close to no obstacles and enemies move 50 tiles per turn and you get surrounded on your second turn everytime. Don't bother with this game. I'm done.
developer_response:
Go INSIDE the dungeon and have encounters scaled to your level, as noted in the tutorial.

Encounters in the overworld/"in front of" the dungeon are NOT scaled to your level.

Also, make use of the terrain and tactics inside the encounter. Most people find the first 10 levels of the game incredibly easy.

Ask for help in chat and you'll find many nice folks in the community happy to help.

I hope you'll give it another shot!

author: {'steamid': '76561198396562470', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 147080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126214, 'last_played': 1617408431}
review: I'm all about the grind and Stash is clearly the game for me :)  I have met alot of friendly and helpful players there from my first minute played to my 2,200 plus hours that I have spent gathering materials, mastering trade skills, building up my Boo "base of operations" and yes you guessed it... getting my GRIND on!! The devs are amazing and interact with players on a daily basis. They have weekly events most of the time and have gave out in game prizes during a few of them.. I could honeslty right a book on why I think you should play Stash but the bottom line is "what do you like" and I know one thing for sure and thats if you enjoy grinding even half as much as I do then please drop in and give this game a chance.. who knows maybe you will become a STASH addict like me :) My main in game is "Lastrites" Look forward to seeing you there :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198034392156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 135949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84368, 'last_played': 1678621055}
review:
Stash is a fun, community driven game. The most important thing to understand about this game is that it's designed to be experience with other people, if you're not bringing a group of friends into the game you should join an active clan upon starting.

You can go it alone and it's just as viable as progressing alongside a group. It's going to be a longer road as far as crafting goes if you try to do everything alone though.

As many others have pointed out in negative reviews, this ia a grinding game, it's designed to be. If you don't enjoy these sorts of games, then Stash is not for you. If you do enjoy grinding games, then Stash is great.

The dev's on most days interacting with the community, events are run regularly. Regular updates including adding new features. This is an indie MMO and it's only been in release for a few months, so it's a little sparse in terms of features at present. There is a roadmap posted on the game forums and a lot of the stuff on there looks great.

Community is great, mostly more mature players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003772256', 'num_games_owned': 68, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2969, 'last_played': 1527134320}
review: For a Game being developed while it's player base is actively playing, STASH is a absolute blast to play, If your looking for something similar to the old pen and paper D&D Stash nails it right off the bat. The devs are easaly reached via discord and are always updating and adding new features.  If your want a game where you can amilessly click your mouse without thinking then go play warcraft. This game requires a little brain power to come out top in combat due to the tatical COMBAT system (IE.  being flanked/pinned/surrounded just like in D&D). I definetly would recomend keeping an eye on this gem and go ahead and click the download button and come join us. The more players the merrier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119157927', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 951, 'last_played': 1527127017}
review:
For a free game id give it 10 out of 10.
Very different from your average RPG's, the fighting style is quite tactical. Lots of loot to get, crafting various items in various  classes. You have a personnel home that you level up and develop (this aspect I really like) also there is a clan equivilent, can group with friends or strangers to do dungeons, there are various task givers with a lot of tasks to be completed.
The style is very table top dungeon and dragons, never thought id really like the style but so far has entertained me working in group fights is even more fun. For me this feels like a true dungeon trawler and its only early access, with the content that is already here so early I really look forward to seeing what is coming. 
Oh ye so far from what ive seen, very decent community. A lot are quick to help and even though the population isnt huge its good enough IMO.
Once things are changed/updated I will redo my review, hopefully even better :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198021469057', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2603, 'last_played': 1590466273}
review:
Old Review part:
Counting from the very start, it took me 10 hours to mostly understand game's basics of:

Combat mechanics, base interaction, renting a stall to sell items to players, how to use traps, crafting, farming the plants and animals and harvesting resources.

I got to know this all by myself, by reading the game's short guides and item descriptions, and especially - curiosity with "Trial and error" method.
Later that time I talked to some player who said that if I wait longer before slaughtering/harvesting the animal/plant - it will produce other materials before it will pass away.

If you have spare 10 hours to slowly get to know this game - all these 3D tabletop styled figures and maquette will become more understandable for you. At least, my curiosity helped me to learn the basics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049639132', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 18059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8288, 'last_played': 1528999869}
review:
If you are a fan of Runescape, then you will like this game.
Stash is in its early stages of development. This means that there are bugs, glitches and unfinished features.
However, the community is active and the developer is constantly working hard to improve this game. 

This game has MASSIVE potential in the future. Get started sooner than later if you want to have the upperhand against your competition!

Pros:
- Its FREE!
- Friendly community with family friendly PG13 rules on globat chat
- More mature players can talk without limitations in 18+ chat
- Active developer that listens to player feedback. Help direct the future of the game!
- Has an "Old School" Runescape feel
- Weekly special events
- Not a "pay to win" game

Cons:
- Starting Tutorial is very simple... almost non existent. (This may be on purpose)
- Extremely time consuming GRIND.
- Limited Map that has not yet been fully implemented.
- Plenty of graphical and UI glitches/ bugs.

Hope you guys found this review helpful and I look foward to playing with you!
My characters name is Frail, if you run in to me send me a shout out!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996947462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1526419263}
review:
Overall, the game isnt too bad. Its VERY grindy. You need a certain number of materials to upgrade your home (Base of Operations - BOO). And grinding mob encounter after mob encounter after mob encounter to find the items is very VERY boring. Im nearing 3 hours in (all 3 hours have been spent DOING something, not sitting around) and I am just level 3. The grind is super slow and the playerbase seems dead. I have tried numberous times to chat and you rarely get a response. The grind to level and the grind to find these items to upgrade your BOO are just pain annoying right now. There are tradesills... but you cant start one until you have a lvl 2 BOO because you can not place the needed item down for tradeskills until you have an "indoor" room. So you are just stuck grinding even more to find those items you need. Tonight I spent 90 minutes trying to find 3 shingles so I can upgrade my BOO. I fought maybe 10-15 fights and managed to find 1... and I am out of storage in my BOO to place the items I looted that I "THINK" I "MAY" need later. So now my inventory is full and no where to place the items. Its quite annoying.

The base of the game is layed out for a much more complex system to be put into place, but as of right now... its just barren. Only 1 "town" to speak of... the game was released Sep 7, 2017. Thats over 8 months ago. Im not sure how the devs havent added more to it. It feels very empty. Like I have stated, its a very repetitive grindfest. 

I am going to say yes to the game for now, simply because I am not very far into it and perhaps it would appeal to other players. I will edit this review once I have more time in the game and make a better decision then.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059194958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1495, 'last_played': 1525864521}
review:
Sorry, but no, I was not impressed. This game seems to be grinding hell to me. There is no storyline. There is very little activity in the chat channels. In the two weeks or so that I played I saw the same 2 dozen names over and over on the map. 
Progress is very slow, crafting is grindy and very slow (unless you buy in game currency for Real Money and spend it to speed up crafting), and there just was not enough variety of gameplay in any way to keep my interest up. 

It looks pretty enough, but there really isn't much game there, in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980366980', 'num_games_owned': 507, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1598689267}
review:
This game is basically a pre-alpha version of what it should be. While it is free to play, there is a serious lack of content to even be posted on steam and get this many positive reviews. There are a total of 23 weapons in the entire game as of now and 13 total monsters. There are 2 sound tracks in the game as well. Gathering items is instanced as well, for some reason or another.
Maybe come back and see how this game is doing in a couple of years if you want a TBS MMO.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123393047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 52002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22972, 'last_played': 1539260391}
review:
The game is very fun, especially if you enjoy crafting and trun based combat. Upgrading your BOO via drops in fights gives a sense of accomplishment. However, this IS a grinding game.

As you grow in player level and crafting level (basically level 20 for both), the game can become more of an exhausted effort due to other players not crafting what you need to excel in your personal craft, or finding people to group with (if you so choose that route).

Combat wise, I enjoyed it at first, however it becomes very redundant closing in milestone levels 15-20. The mobs are not hard, even if you increase the difficulty level of the dungeon. I an currently running +2 difficulty and still falling asleep. And I am a healer running these solo. But there is still a sense of worth as you are gathering materials and recipes for your craft(s).

I do advise the creators to put a little more heart into their events as well. This weekend was supposed to be a mystery visitor who sold numerous things from mounts to bag space, etc. Unfortunately this particular event is run by one person. So whenever he/she decides to log in to the "mystery visitor" then there basically isn't one. It is a poor choice for an "event" when it is contingent on Snarlax (GM) to log in on said visitor.

Hope the game grows, because it is still fun. I think it has much potential if more players join and continue to level up their professions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046018819', 'num_games_owned': 841, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1523502945}
review:
Stash is certainly not the typical MMO, it has a unique turn based twist that sort of gives it a fresh take on the genre. So far it feels somewhat challenging, as there is a complexity that comes with it right as you get started (specially without a tutorial in-game) but luckily enough, it doesn't feel intimidating so far. If anything, it gives it a different pace providing a more rewarding experience in terms of strategy based gameplay.

I like the fact that the game seems to be oriented towards crafting instead of questing. There are tasks, but it feels like a sand-box design to it that allows you to tailor your own MMO experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116322634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1265, 'last_played': 1529960670}
review:
Not sure if to give a thumb up or down. I would take a "neutral" if it was available.
Stash is basically a sand-boxy (no given storyline, pick "fighting/crafting/tasks/camp-upgrade whenever you want" system) game that plays online. You can join people in shared dungeons, do private dungeons or trade with them. 
The dungeons are a bit peculiar compared to common fare: Every encounter (open world or dungeons) is depicted by a board game like piece similar to your character, some moving around every so often, pretty much all easily evaded if you want to. Dungeons seem to have no "end". There might be a boss encounter placed somewhere and you might have to fight your way to this if other encounter block the way. But you won't find treasure chests outside of the "encounter finished" moment of the encounter. So it seems that "clearing" a dungeon if there is no boss encounter to be reached is not giving more rewards than fighting the same number of encounter in the open world. The dungeons just have encounter more concentrated in a smaller area and they are more themed than in the open world.

The loot is random gear for different classes, crafting ingredients, seeds, animals for husbandry, furniture, BOO upgrade parts. BOO is "base of operation", you could say your personal camp. You can upgrade and equip it with crafting stations, gardens, coops, barns etc. It is similar to farmville as in you have to unlock space and slots for storage/buildings/room sizes/yard space/crafting stations by ingame money and particular items (RNG loot, relatively rare). Or you can buy the latter in the microtransaction store for either ingame money (rather a lot) or real money.

You can buy some basic items from NPC in the capital, but the majority of items of better value seem to come from loot or especially crafting. Food is very valuable as it refills your HP and Mana points which you deplete in encounter. But while you can have orchards, gardens , coops and barns available and might be a chef selling your items at a market stall ... the necessary structures need a LOT of very LITTLE space in your BOO yard and the first tier (tiny ... coop/barn ...) only accept 2 seeds/saplings/animals, whose products you can't use directly but have to process to useable items. Even eggs have to be produced into "raw eggs" ... For which you need an expensive machine which needs to be placed inside the main building at your BOO ... which you have to unlock first and then it has only 6 slots. A processing machine needs 2 slots. Of course each actual crafting station takes another, for example your stove. And your animals or plants have a very limited life span during which they produce consistently, but they only produce until the storage space(Stash!) of the structure is full - but that space is tiny. So you better play often and constantly move things (into your VERY small STASH storage ... which you can upgrade ... yadda yadda) - or (later) you pay money to buy larger ones. Which need space and permission to be placed. Which you need to unlock.
It is basically this quickly escalating grind-in-circles thing to progress or you have not much to do. But that can be fine for people who are happy to just do some mindless little thing.

Here is the real problem in my opinion with Stash: the user interface is so unintuitive and convoluted that it takes people in chat to answer help calls because not even the wiki is useful. For example the character sheet has a little drop down menu which you won't realize. If you buy in the in-game shop something with ingame currency it is not placed into your inventory. It is placed into an extra "rewards inventory" only accessible via that drop down. Or you have an action bar - but it shows only if you are in an encounter or actively open it by going through another menu. And then it has 4 bars (combat, non-combat items etc) which you can only switch there but not if you have one bar open on itself and you need to eat but that can't be done on the combat bar. Or if you want to do any farming or husbandry you need to get the coops etc from a special merchant. All merchants are at the entrance level of the town - except the ones dealing with this. To find those you have to realize that the city has 4 levels and the stairs in one corner can be climbed if you click them right. Because everything is pathfinding by clicking at the floor but the stairs need to be hit "right". And then you spend a LONG time watching your figure piece sliding around from level to level to get to the top and those merchants, get the tasks, slide ALL the way back to the bottom level and outside, fullfill the tasks, get back to the city, slide all the way ... You catch the gist. A player told me you can at least have your figure do the whole thing automatically (but still as slow) by clicking at the wall supporting the highest level. Yay. Now I click, tab out, do something else, maybe remember to go back, interact with the npc, click the city gate for the way back, tab out ...
There are more example but I think that illuminates those really mind boggling designs.

The second thing that is really off putting - and I would never have thought I had such an issue with a game ever, I tend to always have the standard music on - is the music and sound effects. The music is bad, monotonous, constantly omnious, always the same except for encounter it seems. I switched it off entirely. The sound effects are very bad too. I play a cat and I'm close to switching those off too because the constantly yowl when I get hit is getting on my nerves.

I assume the UI and music/sound is an EA effect and I think Stash could find its niche. But right now it is VERY much an EA game. But hey, it is free ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198061230879', 'num_games_owned': 189, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1523346299}
review:
With just a bit more than a hour of consecutive gameplay, this game already burned my patience.

To begin with, the world map music, is the same as the city music and the INN music.
When you change maps, If the music on the map you entered is the same as the music 
from the map you just left, It doesn't matter, the music will be RESETTED! So you'll probably 
grow sick of it any minute soon.
The menu and character selection have no music, and you most likelly will get a jumpscare 
when the battle music begins, since It is way louder than the other game musics, aswell 
as more agitated, the other musics of the game are so calm and quiet, somewhat, but 
the battle music is intense and loud.

Unless you check the game help session, you will most likelly be lost in the game, since 
you'll be unable to make use of almost everything in the game, I still don't even know how 
to set a damn campfire. The explorability of the game content is really bad, If you try to learn 
to play the game by exploring what It has to offer, you'll only get anger and frustration, on my 
last minutes online, I were even having agony of playing the game, since not only I didn't knew 
how to craft things, but also had no idea how to restore my character health and mana, other 
than using food.

The crafting in the game is also kinda bad, beside the fact you need to find either encounter of 
the resources through the map, or have the luck of the resources you need to appear in a battle 
against enemy npcs, you actually need to have on the inventory the correct tool to gather that 
resource, so you need to go to the town and buy the tool, aswell as learn your first profession 
(Yes, I didn't found any sense when I found out that, even after I setup my char as a blacksmith). 
You need also to buy from the town npcs the crafting tables, and also guess what you need to 
craft an item, because the game doesn't tell you what you need to craft the item, and If you have not the 
tool to craft the item, the game wont tell you what tool you need, will only say you doesn't 
have the correct tool to craft the item.

The bed at your base, you can't use, so you can't restore your character health and mana, 
and since there is no idea of how to place a campfire, and the INN at the town seems to 
be some kind of battleground against the wind, the game is basically a battle 'till you drop, 
since you have to use the food you get on towns, or even the looted food to restore your 
health and mana.

This game also repeats a mistake that most mmos have, this game has 5 races, 2 of them 
you can select the gender, the others are gender locked, seriously, just why there is no 
other gender variant of the race? If your want to make a female Lycor (whatever is the name of 
the race), you will have to content yourself with the Warrior class, because other than that, 
you may attempt the Cat race.

Other than the rantings, this game surelly would look cooler If they removed that floor bellow the 
characters, and made them WALK, instead of slide through the map, because that makes the game 
look monotome when walking around, and kills part of the magic during the battle, If is to make 
the character behave like a piece of board game, would be better if It gave little hops when moving.

The combat in the game is quite generic, but is somewhat acceptable, but If you don't want to be 
bored, better party up with other people, and charge on higher leveled enemies, or try alone and 
rely on foods.

For some reason, the town npcs are shown as portals on the map, where when you step on it, their 
dialogue appears, I wonder, why didn't they made so the town npcs are shown on the map as their 
former self? If the problem were the fact that the players could aglomerate on it, then they could 
make so the players stop near it before talking.

Anyway, just due to the fact this game is a pain, I don't recommend it on the current state, but feel 
free to try it at your own risk. Also, that game for some reason made me want to play Wakfu, even 
though I hate the combat system of the game, at least is easier to learn how to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989103196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3012, 'last_played': 1607738741}
review:
So after logging 50 hours I thought I would write a short review. First things first, I do recommend this game, on a few conditions:
[list]
    [*]You enjoy slow paced gameplay
    [*]You can set your own target
    [*]You don't mind unpolished features
[/list]

Ok, so if you hear "RPG", and expect to be handheld through a smooth journey laid out like an interactive movie, then this game is not for you. I only reached level 10(current max level is 40), but it was a haul just to get there. It was a haul I enjoyed, but not because of the scenery. You will spend a lot of time clearing the same dungeons over and over, a task best done in groups, because it can be painfully slow solo. This game is best enjoyed in groups overall, groups where noone is in a hurry. At the moment the playerbase is small, and finding someone to grind with can be difficult(at least with my awkward hours, playing from Japan), but the people you do find beyond level 5 are all relaxed and nice people to spend time with. And that's what a game is about, isn't it? Spending time with nice people.. 
The game makes a point about not explaining more than it has to, but grasping the basics is really not difficult, and I believe the game is built on some good concepts, like player crafting being a core feature rather than a side track. It needs more polishing, and could see some improvements on playability, but I think it's a very good work in progress. I hope it can attract more players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031481829', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1510595270}
review: I like Stash because it hearkens back to my pen and paper days of exploring a rich world. I found the mechanics of combat to be familiar even on the first time playing. I'm a rather meandering sort and travel about the map heedlessly. I find this game appealing from the visuals to the open-ended nature that caters to my exploratory nature. I recommend this game to all of my friends who enjoyed pen and paper and are looking for a way to while away some hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198825481469', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1522053628}
review: Great game to come across.  So far a lot of fun to play.  Gameplay style is very unique and very suited to my pace.  I am already wrapped up in crafting and it's only been a few hours. Well done, Frogdice!

author: {'steamid': '76561198822884728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1046, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1046, 'last_played': 1521253648}
review:
Browsing different F2P games, and decided to give this one a whirl.  Very pleasantly surprised and found myself spending the last few days playing whenever I had some spare time.  Absolutely LOVE that I can pick it up and go whenever I want and jump right into some combat.

Speaking of combat, it seems very simple at first, but then as I learned, it requires me to sharpen my skills and really think about what I'm going to do.  I really like that it isn't mindless.

Big fan so far, and I look forward to logging more hours!
