author: {'steamid': '76561198068693289', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2770, 'last_played': 1523084937}
review:
This isn't really a review so much as an extended comment on someone else's review, but I thought that this would help clear up some misunderstandings about a game that took me a little while to get into, but that I've completely fallen in love with, and will continue to play for the forseeable future. 

The original review can be seen here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/metsushiro/recommended/466660/


As a recently joined player that got past the first hour or so of this game, I'd like to point a few things out to you. I'm not saying you're wrong to be disappointed in the first little bit of the game, because you're probably used to how games throw everything at you all at once and force you into a handholdy tutorial in which you learn maybe a tenth of what they show you because it's throwing so much in your face. This game's main feature is that it doesn't do that. It's intentional. 

Some of the things you pointed out as flaws aren't actually a thing, you just didn't play long enough to see that. Maybe consider trying the game again some time? Maybe it's still not your thing, but here's the knowledge you should have before you make your final decision on whither to play again or not, addressed piece by piece in the order it's relevant. 

The housing system in this game IS exactly as you heard, but you need to spend the time to upgrade your Base of Operations once or twice before it really opens up for customization. You can put many different types of crafting stations, decorations, and furniture both inside and outside your home, and you can quite easily (if not cheaply) change the colour of the interior walls and floors of your home from the cash shop. Note that while the option of paying real money to make these changes is available, it is NOT necessary, as you can buy them with the in-game currency too, as with almost everything else in the cash shop. 
Yes, the game is grindy, that's literally the whole point of the genre. This game is a real RPG, not the watered-down thing people call an RPG now; you can spend years working on a character and have that progress actually mean something. You will always have something more to work on, and someone won't join up some day three years from now, pay $4000, and immediately be better than you in every way. 
The combat was slow-paced because you didn't know what you were doing. Every game is like that. You pick up speed as you learn the mechanics, and they roll out more mechanics for you to learn as you level up and unlock more skills. Most turns take me less than a second. 

The game has quests, lore, and storyline. All you have to do is look for it. It actually says that in one of those tutorial screens that you skipped, the moment you enter the town for the first time. Yes, the story isn't as fleshed out as it is in Skyrim, but for one they haven't spent millions of dollars and several years with a team of hundreds of people working on it, and for two this is something they are actively adding to, and will continue to do so for decades to come, if their reputation has even a bit of truth to it. 

You'd be hard-pressed to find ANY game where you can ignore everything and dash into a dungeon and somehow have any sense of story. Maybe a D&D session, i guess? Even then, only if your DM isn't thrown off by it and decides to crush you with a falling meteor because you're trying to circumvent his existance. You don't have a map because they are small pseudo-labrynths that aren't hard to navigate at all if you have any directional sense. You can fit almost the entire dungeon on screen at once if you zoom out. The combat was basic because you were level one. You try finding a game where they give you every skill in the game at level one, and then tell me how interesting that game was for the five minutes you played it before realizing there was nothing to do because you kill everything too easily. 

Of course the fights are instanced, there are other people playing that want experience too. Is the only mmorpg you've played Maplestory? If so, you should know how much of a problem people hogging all the enemies on a screen is there; you have to scan through twenty channels to find one where you won't get yelled at for trying to complete your quest. That isn't an issue with instanced combat, there are more than enough spawns for any number of players, even if they all happen to be doing the same quest. You can gather crafting materials from anything that is shiny in a fight, and there is a chest at the end of literally every single fight with "exciting treasures and surprises" in it. I don't know if there are fights later on that have field hazards as a game mechanic, I'm only level six so far and it could be rolled out later as something new has been added to the dynamics of combat literally every level at the point i'm at in the game. Even if they don't, I think the combat system is fine how it is. 

The very first guide that shows up the moment you log in to the game explains that you can read all of the guides at any point using the menus in the bottom right. they are there 100% of the time, even when you're in battle. Certain pages of these guides make more sense when you have a point of reference to say "Oh yeah, that's what that was!", and these show up when they are relevant, which is exactly what a well-designed tutorial does. 

Everyone is entitled to their own opinion and I'm not saying anything as an attack to you personally, I'm sure you're a well-educated person that loves gaming in their spare time, like most of the people from the last two generations. I only want to point out that you simply cannot see any of the depth of a game in less than an hour, especially in the sea of MMO's, where it's the little differences that make a gem of a game like this one stand out all the more. Please do consider giving it another go if you ever have the time, it really has so much more to it than you've seen, and likely than I've seen, too. 

TL;DR It isn't a good idea to judge every aspect of a game with such a brief glance at it. You'll miss the best ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965396869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 237, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1521293488}
review:
Played for almost 45 minutes... and that felt like about 30 minutes too long.  It needs a lot of work.  Graphics are dull, interface is poorly designed, sounds are not very good, character creation is lame.  About the only good thing about character creation is that you have a lot of colour choices.  Races are boring, +x to one stat, no other differences.  Backgrounds mean nothing.  You were a blacksmith?  Cool.  Gives you a bonus to blacksmithing or strength or heat tolerance?  Nope.  You were a Gypsy(Steam Censors that?  Really?)?  Give you a bonus to making camp, lore or any travel related skills?  Nope.  You were a noble?  Got better gear?  More money?  Authority of some kind?  Special title?  Nope.

You can activate abilities that give you bonuses for a real time duration.  Yeah.  In a turn based game.  So the faster you do things in a TURN BASED GAME the longer that ability "lasts" until you have to re-activate it.

Combat was dull as heck and the three strategic bonuses or penalties were pretty stupid and pointless at low levels where they give small % bonuses.  As with all games that use % damage buff or debuff, or % based damage mitigation there's an issue when damage output, or incoming damage, is 2 or 3 points.  I don't care if a 2 point hit gets reduced to 1.8 rounded up..... because it does NOTHING.  I don't care if my 28 damage swing suddenly does 31 if all enemies have about 40 health.  I have to hit them twice with, or without, the bonus so it does NOTHING.  Ok, enough about that.

I usually enjoy turn based strategy games but this one was so dull, so absolutely lifeless and poorly designed, that I didn't care to keep playing long enough to see if it gets any better.  If a game is really good it will hook you almost immediately, not make you want to stop playing within minutes.... and that's about all I have to say.

author: {'steamid': '76561198173058777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1521229434}

Não tem BR, mas você consegue entrar em partys facilmente, o jogo é de turno e isso eu acho bem da hora, mas infelizmente é um tipo de jogo de turno simples, não tem como comparar com Divinity, até porque o jogo é gratuito, mas se voce tiver paciencia, vale a pena jogar por uns minutos pra ver se atrai sua atenção ou não. Eu recomendo fortemente jogar com amigos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026432447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 1015, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1015, 'last_played': 1521522226}
review:
This is the third time I've attempted to write a review of this game. This will be last time.

In a nutshell:

The game is extremely basic. As an ex game designer, I would call this game an engine preview to offer to management for development consideration. Nothing more. 

This game has no story, no quests, and does nothing to keep you interested in the game. You create a character, you enter the world, and you kill monsters. That's it. Yes, you can explore. Yes, you can craft. Yes, you can build your house. But my point is that there is nothing in this game to excite me to come back to the game and pursue those things.

As for the DLC, buyer beware. Both packages, in my opinion, are a waste of money. There are far superior, full games available on Steam, that cost the same or less than the DLC that is offered. For example: Any of the Final Fantasy series.

I would recommend this game only for those who like doing mindless killing and grinding levels when they just want to pass time. Otherwise, don't bother.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073336726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 137104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22499, 'last_played': 1584317536}

Just one more encounter, I only have to be at work in 2 hours... I can do it. Strangely addictive.  A bit of a grind at times but great community and good things seem to be in the developing works.  Give it a try.  Its free, what the hell?

author: {'steamid': '76561198011492573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6906, 'last_played': 1661647264}
review:
My wife and I have been playing Stash now for about a week and while it has it quirks overall it is a fun game. Brings back memories of other games and the play style. Its also wonderful to have a game where crafters make items that are better than the world drops so makes crafters important.
If you want a startegy style game with no point click or action combat you may like this game it makes you plan and strategize your combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108168219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 60871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11992, 'last_played': 1591238720}
review: I really love this game it is playable and fun now and gets better with each update. Don't miss this game it's something very special. Different classes compliment each other well and make combat more interesting. Great group of helpful people playing that can help you learn but I recommend reading the guide for beginners for your own benefit. I enjoy playing alone and teaming up with others it keeps it dynamic. Crafting and quests are available as well and make this a well rounded grame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128658183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1519463723}
review:
I heard this mmo has a great housing system, and since mmos and custom housing are my thing, I tried it out on a whimp. Stash is exactly as advertised; very grindy, repetitive, cute graphics, has no quests and has a very very (painfully) slow combat pace.

The game itself lacks of a storyline and objectives. As you finish creating your character, you will find yourself between 2 dungeons and your home, with only an arrow on the floor to guide you (no tutorials). 

At this point, there is no purpose to stay at home since we have nothing to customize with. Not even the colour of our beginner home can be changed; leaving us with nothing to look forward to.

On to our first dungeon! Once inside, there are once again, no story involved. Your only motivation is your will to kill everything. At first glance, we were quickly disappointed that a map wasn't available. In confusion as to the whereabouts we should be going, we decided to go on forth towards our first enemy! Engaging in combat will teleport you to an instance and that is where you fight. Click tile, select skill, hurt enemy; repeat until enemy is dead. Exit instance, walk up to next enemy, enter instance, kill, repeat. While the basics are there, the combat is bare and not engaging whatsoever. 

It would be much more interactive if the fight was taking place directly onto the dungeon's ground (no need to load an instance) and if the surroundings could affect the combat; whereas if you step on a fire tile, you will catch on fire and receive "fire status." Or have the ability to break crates / chests for exciting treasures and surprises.

Every now and again a quick guide will pop up, explaining the functions of things. We were confused as to why the guides appeared after we've seen said functions, and not prior to. For example, you will receive a 'pinned' or 'surrounded' status in combat and (while these are pretty straightforward) the explanation appeared only after we defeated the instanced fight. We can't help but wonder if a short tutorial should have been implemented to help ensure a smooth and uninterupted gameplay.

Whilst we've played and enjoyed many other turn based RPGs, Stash sadly is not deep nor unique as it claims to be. We were not entertained in the slightiest bit and most of our gameplay was spent wondering why we weren't playing something else.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074629020', 'num_games_owned': 269, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1518724345}
review:
Unspielbar unter Linux (Charakter konnte nicht erstellt werden) und keine Unterstützung:

[...]
We are not a full time Linux developer and only create Linux builds of our games because
so many Linux gamers have asked us too. It is not something we are able to fully support
ourselves. I hope you can understand.
developer_response:
Our game is free and we are very clear up front that we cannot afford to provide active Linux support. We have a self-help thread on the forums and have a history of implementing fixes that the Linux community finds. 

Giving a game a negative review for being unable to afford active Linux support sends one clear message to developers: Don't make a Linux build. It can only hurt you.

We have hundreds, possibly thousands, of hours of time invested in Linux specific bug fixes, making Linux builds, and uploading Linux builds every single time we have an update/patch. The value of that time is far greater than any sales we have ever made from all Linux copies of all games we have ever published in the history of the company. 

Look at Steam's hardware survey.

http://store.steampowered.com/hwsurvey/

0.25% of Steam users run Linux. What kind of time do you reasonably think any studio - especially an indie studio - can afford to invest in Linux support?

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197995410143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10988, 'last_played': 1531685870}
review:
I have not played many hours of Stash, imo, but I hope this review sheds light for interested patrons. I will update the review once I feel I have a satisfactory #  of hours played. 

The game is AMAZING. Though more slower paced than most instant gratification games, if you want loot chests with your mothers credit card stay away, I believe this game has the most potential of all MMO's I've played in the recent years. I've barely cracked the surface of Stash and i'm LOVING it. Do you want full immersion in a world of dev God's and player plebs? Stash has it. Do you want to run dungeons and destroy mobs at a lower/higher level than you? Stash has it! Ever wanted to sit in your house while farming and crafting gear for hours at the same time as you sleep next to someone waiting for the immenant chaos to ensue? STASH HAS IT!

The world of Grind stash brings has never been so real. I've been waiting for a game to grind my heart away and I've found it. I'm all about the ding I'm all about the plox and I'm all about the subtle RP that confuses most but inspires the rest.

The dev's are always there, theyre always watching, they hear/see all the feedback and act accordingly from it. 

tldr: If you want a game that feels like WoW did back in it's vanilla days, if you want a game you can fall asleep to and wake up like its irl, if you want a game that will keep you smiling until you realize you should have slept 4 hours prior Then  IMO this is the game for you. 

Give it a try, I did and 80 hrs later I'm hooked and cant log out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030173931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2559, 'last_played': 1538710882}
review:
The devs in this game are more active than any game I have ever played.  My first weekend in Stash, and 2 devs were in chat, helping people out, answering questions, and guiding anyone that needed assistance.

The game itself is grindy, and not for the faint hearted.  However, for someone like myself, I see this as a positive.  Higher levels are a true achievement, and to be respected.  If you see someone high level, or on the leader boards, you will know they put in serious time, and are likely very knowledgeable in the game.  Stash also is very simple on the surface, but as you level, the game generally does a good job of slowly explaining its many complex mechanics, while also remaining a true open world where you don't feel like you are on rails and being dragged along on a ride.

Overall, I highly recommend this game, and have brought 5 friends into it already, and intend to bring 3 more soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023022660', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1169, 'last_played': 1518333690}
review:
This game is grind city. If you want to do the same shit over and over to grind out ridiculous XP requirements even for low levels, this game is for you! Took me almost 20 hours to go from level 1-7, and I was still doing the basic shit I was doing when I started.

Oh, and I mentioned how grindy I was finding the game in chat and one of the devs got pissy at me for "playing it wrong".

A really, really solid core concept mired in shitty F2P game design. Sorry Frogdice.

review: I enjoyed how unique the character creation was, with some very cool races. I also loved how I was able to jump right into combat as soon as I started. author: {'steamid': '76561198048900115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1517989371}
review:
kinda stupid, way too grindy, no help whatsoever, communty of gamers is full of angry trolls.  

Yes I suppose I have to elaborate on these points so ok....ok so grindy isn't bad but in this game its so repetetive, boring, and without any innovation whatsoever.   One thing that sucks is that there are limited mobs such as like only 10 enemy types or the fact that the game uses stupid pedestals for your character instead of walking animations, the fact that the main city is large it takes a long time to walk up to the top floor for some quest givers which is unnecessary.  I did play into a few levels of the game and got a crafting skill up a bit so I have played the game.  Also, it is pay to win as certain things like multiple crafting skills have to be purchased with real money.  Chat is mostly completely dead in the game if you ask a question one of the five or so regular players will angrily shout "READ THE WIKI!!" and if you mention pay to win they say "IT IS NOT PAY TO WIN!!"  The wiki isn't much help right now as it is all voluntary player based input and very minimal..

Someone else mentioned how stupid it is that the game loads you into resource nodes where you just move around a few squares and harvest it.  Why not just harvest it from the map?  LOL its insanely stupid but I won't go into detail since that horse has been beaten bloody in other reviews.

LOL just add walking animations and get rid of those ugly pedestals and it would gain +1

author: {'steamid': '76561198020533045', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3885, 'last_played': 1518393750}
review:
Well, let's see... Plenty to say...

Classes: 
Only a very basic selection (Warrior, mage, healer, and archer variety). Each class has very different skill sets, and stats affect each class differently. Armor for each class is based on the old school D&D theory; mage stays in cloth, Healer starts in leather, but can upgrade to chain later. Archer can start in leather, but upgrade to ring mail. Warrior starts in chain, and can use plate later. Each class serves a different function, and this definitely adds a strategic layer to combat (more on combat later).

BoO:
Base of Operations; this is your house/crafting factory/farm/personal space. If you want to design a swanky spot, go for it. Me, however... I went for the sweat shop vibe, with crafting stations all over the place. As you use resources to level up your BoO, you get more space to put things, can have more than one crafting station for the same craft class, and so forth...

Crafting:
Six main crafts: Cooking, Enchanting, Armor, Weapons, Alchemy, Making (think tools and furniture and crafting stations). Each recipe requires multiple mats, as is usual. There are various harvesting skills as well: Trapping, salvage, mining, herbs, lumber, gems, skinning, and farming. All of this functions into a well crafted, albeit a bit grindy, crafting ecosystem.

A caveat to add here: Each character can only have one crafting profession to start. You can either purchase an expansion with the cash shop currency, or you can buy the expansion with in-game funds from a player that bought it in the cash shop.

Combat: 
Think.... Baldur's gate meets final fantasy tactics. Turn based, tactical combat on a grid-based map. Groups of up to 6 (Maybe 5), and the fights can actually take quite a bit of time. They require the use of CC, heals, kiting, damage, gear that is level appropriate... all of the makings for a solid challenge. Dungeons, currently, are a single floor, and not completely fleshed out, but they are full of stuff to kill and loot to collect.

Cash shop: 
Thankfully, most things in the cash shop can be bought for cash shop currency OR in-game currency. The only things that cannot be bought directly from the cash shop for in-game currency are: additional character slots, the largest of the backpacks, some cosmetic items, and additional crafting skill slots. These things CAN, however, be purchased for in-game currency from other players that have purchased them with cash shop currency.

Trading:
Reminiscent of Oldschool Everquest; you want to sell stuff? Either toss it up in trade chat and find a buyer, or set it for sale at your own personal stall. This actually puts you into better contact with the community and engages you with it, bring back the need to actually play with other people.

Overall:
All of that said, YES, I would recommend the game, but I will sum up some pros and cons.

PROS: 
-The game has depth. Combat and crafting are intricate, engaging, require thought, and will keep you busy. There is no empty clicking and walking away for 30 minutes while you craft 20 stacks of stuff. It is involved, but in a good way.
- Accessibility for those with no real world funding. If you can't spend cash on it, you can but it with in-game currency
- The community is great. There aren't trolls, everyone is helpful, and the moderators and Devs are fully involved with the community, both in-game and on the community forums.
- Almost 50 hours, as of this review, and I have run into no bugs or crashes. Probably one of the smoothest early access games I have ever played.

Cons:
-A niche game with a smaller community, and it may not be for everyone
-Possibility of RMT abuse if people with the cash want to flood the market with cash shop items, essentially "buying gold". This could lead to some debate.
-The game is still very rough. Dungeons aren't fully fleshed out. There are invisible walls on the map to keep folks within the current early access area. Max level is currently 25, as they implement the higher content. Yes, it is Early access, but people tend to have issues with this.
-Can feel like a super grind at times. If you aren't up for grinding, whether it be harvesting, crafting, or hunting, then this probably isn't for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038101849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2570, 'last_played': 1562864725}
review:
Pros:
- Can have up to 6 people in party
- Game runs very smoothly
- Dev is very involved in game
- Random instances keep for an interesting experience
- Stays true to table top games for flanking and disadvantages on attacks.
- Very well done in game help guide with clickable index for finding just what you are lookings for.
- Great in game community. Very friendly and helpful.

Cons:
- When you don't have the right equipment for harvesting it does not indicate which equipment you need.
--- Maybe better if the bosses were a private instance that did not go unavailable when other parties enter.
- Hard to communicate on the battle field due to the grid not having any indicators such as alphanumeric columns and rows.
- Harvesting items during battle is not intuitive and I personally could not find anything in the guide. However the community did help me through the process.


Overall I have really enjoyed this game and will continue to play and support the community. Hope to see you in the game.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198809538018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3264, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3264, 'last_played': 1517288002}
review: Really enjoying this game from the start. The combat is engaging but not overwhelming, and I really love the custom avatars!  The flexibility when designing your BOO is incredible.  Give it a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007324723', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7996, 'last_played': 1518544648}
review:
If youre sick of taking a crafting profession only to craft 2 or 3 profitable items until the end game you might wanna give this game a go. The crafting professions are useful and needed for a healthy player based economy like this game has, Im enjoying a lot selling food and weapons in the marketplace. The combat seems simple at start but you will see soon that you get 1 skill per lvl (I dont know if thats true for every lvl, at least until lvl 10, max is 30 if Im not mistaken) so it gives you more options to make strategies and enemies and battle get way more complicated over time. It still needs content but the devs are working hard and it has more than enoough to be enjoyed. Game masters are always in game, resolving questions and doing events, theyre pretty friendly.
Crafting: 9/10 (When they add more stuff is gonna be def a 10)
Combat: 8/10 (Enjoyable but can get repetitive, luckily you can party with anyone no matter what lvl and the lower lvl gets a stat boost)
System req: 10/10 (You can run this game with a potato while still looking fairly good thanks to the artstyle)

author: {'steamid': '76561198436106304', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1511375045}

author: {'steamid': '76561198036644354', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4698, 'last_played': 1682720734}
review:
Great game. 100% Recommended.

If you are looking for a Turn-Based MMO you should try Stash 100%.

Has crafting, old school trading with stalls, in-game news paper or Trade Channel, you can have your own piece of land to call "Home" (Instanced tho) Scalable Dungeon difficulty, can do stuff solo or in groups, friendly community and IN GAME ACTIVE GM's that even tho they are working, they'll help whenever they can.

The start is a bit confusing, because there are some aspects that work differently from other games, but once you go thro your firsts levesl you'll understand everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045566501', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 18480, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3102, 'last_played': 1518414860}
review:
Oh boy where do i begin with this gem of an MMO, first impression was very boring if i were to be honest, but as you gradually meet the community, the dev whos constantly in the game named Snarlax who constantly does PSA and whom you can confine to in regards to the game and the mechanics and the fact they have a discord makes eeverything different.

Imagine if you will Dungeons and Dragons, now that feel as an MMO, can imagine how chaotic it can be as your making decissions on your turn with timers, in a party of 6, it is uber fun and less boring, speically with the benefits and the battles that scales to your party rank.

I highly recommend this game to those seeking a quiet MMO where you can farm, and have a slice at life whilst at the same time going on an adventure, to me honestly, its like the Anime Log Horizon, really felt that way, i hope this game never dies, and its community keeps growing, at the very least the devs actually listens to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198806988474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1516331441}
review: Am excited to be able to start decorating my own base, because I really like crafting elements in games, and this one seems to have lots of it. I'm also not big on rushing through things so the fact that I can take my time in combat is also a huge plus. All in all seems a good game to run in the background and play idly or just grind through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994307165', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1516395231}
review:
I had high hopes for the game. It looked simple with some basic features. Unfortunately those features don't work 99% of the time. 

-The starting gear I received didn't match my class. The only gear I picked up was for the mage class. Not sure if that's intentional but I had 15+ articles of gear, all for the mage. Not one was for any other class. I'm an archer.

-The first mob I ran into had 3x my health and killed me instantly (in a level 1 area). Mobs that deal 50 damage are labeled under the same level and difficulty as those dealing 3 damage. Luck of the draw of who you run into as a level 1.

-The mob encounter shows only one mob. Once you enter the instance, it could be 1 monster at your level or it could be 4 monsters at your level.

-The game wants you to party up but after an hour, I found no other players. Saw some ads "LFG" for level 20+. Nothing beyond that.

-I managed to buy a lvl 1 axe but it can't gather lvl 1 wood. I've been able to harvest some lvl 1 wood; but then walk 10 feet to the side and not be able to harvest the same lvl 1 wood. The exact–same–wood.

-The camera angle is absolutely horrible. You can't move it in combat. You can only rotate it. So if your character is on the other side of the entire area, you have to play them from long-distance and hope you're clicking on the right tiles. If you rotate the camera to your character, they're blocked by your skill bar and chat box. 

-Gender-specific classes. 

-Skill info tips are wrong. Light damage vs moderate damage = 25 damage vs 20 damage. Not sure what's going on there.

-My archer can shoot an arrow 3 squares but melee units can also hit from 3 squares. So what's the point? Image provided where I'm getting hit by the units with melee attacks. You can also see that I tried to harvest the resource and couldn't, despite having the proper harvesting tool. https://imgur.com/a/P5liK

-All units can move 4 squares each turn. Why be a fast rogue when you can be a just as fast tank? 

-No map in the game. 

-Melee does WAY more than any spell/arrow. I was literally melee smacking people with my bow because it does more damage than my bow skills. Melee hit does 30+ and arrows do ~15.

-No auction house. 

-The stores are very random. All the NPCs are just labeled as "Merchant". No idea who sells what.

-Other players can put up shops but without an auction house, no one knows what anything is worth. 

-Most of the chat is roleplay. 

-I saw some people trying to trade in chat but literally everyone trading kept argueing about the price of items. I don't think any trades actually happened. It's not like the prices were off by a few items. Some players are saying an item is worth 20 and other players are saying it's worth 300.

-No moving animation. Not a horrible thing but it looks extra cheesy to have your person float around on a platform, sliding from zone to zone. 

-You have to enter a new instance of the game to gather resources. I'm not kidding about this. You literally have to load an entirely different instance on each resource you gather. You approach the resource, the game asks if you if you want to harvest, you click yes, it sends you to another dimension with a random amount of resources around you. It's not a smooth transition either. There's a whole load screen and map construction for each resource you try to harvest. Sometimes the axe works, most of the time it doesn't. Luck of the draw.

Put an hour into the game and just ran into one disaster after another.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-After the response of the GM-

Hello Ringold! I was actually coming back here to say that the in-game mods/admin were trying to be helpful and such. I'm glad you reached out. 

The game has arrows that kept pointing me into dungeons. I get into the dungeon and walk around. Only mob I run into is the boss. This happened over and over. Eventually I found some mobs farther out and leveled up some.

Yes, Axe issues. In some areas of the game, the wood would harvest normally. But 80% of the time, it wouldn't. Same name of wood. Same level area. Very luck of the draw. Not sure what was going on. Used the same method on each harvest. Each harvest was the same wood.
Got you some screen shots buddy:
Doesn't seem to be working
https://imgur.com/a/Mnlak

Is this the wrong axe for level 1 wood?
https://imgur.com/a/XeQul

Oh and, let me know which tool I need to loot a dead body because apparently this is a problem as well: https://imgur.com/a/AhBfr

I tried the camera angles. I did. I went through the tutorial and everything. After mentioning it in game. You commented to use scroll in and such. All of which I was doing and it was working as intended. However, I could not move my camera from the original focus point of the plane. I could only rotate my camera around and zoom in+out. It left for very awkward angles as I mentioned in my review.

Yes, I mentioned the instances. Good job reciting what I pointed out. You can't just click on it? That's kind of the point here. I mean, even RuneScape has that down. Your current process is: click use button (optional), click item, confirm you want to harvest, load area, click harvest tool, harvest, back button, load area. Holy shit. (I need to confirm this order. Hold on.)... I got that order for ya. I found out that I can just run into the thing. So that's pretty nifty. But here ya go: Run to the harvestable item, Confirm you want to harvest the harvestable item, load area, find the harvestable items, click on harvest tool, use harvest tool, click on harvest tool, use harvest tool, click on exit button, confirm exit, load area. There's a section in there that isn't needed.

Maps ruin immersion? Uhh.. no. What's the first thing an adventurer should do when finding a new area? Map it out! You see.. throughout history, humans have explored the unknown world; charting the lands in what is now known as a map. A map of an area is very useful. It lets you know if there's a town nearby or if you're just walking off into the distance and nothing is ahead of you. As small as your world is, I got lost a couple times and had to use a teleport to get back home. A map breaks immersion but teleporting in and out of existance isn't? I'm a level 1 with a global range teleportation skill but I can't hold a map. You guys are funny.

Since we're on the topic about "trying to keep the game immersive", I'll refer you back to the loading screen problem. Every time I gather a resource, I have to enter a new plane of existance. Which resets the music and ambient sounds. Then it restarts again when you re-enter the world. Kind of a loss of immersion there. Why not just, oh I don't know, not have a seperate instance for each resource?

Game wasn't super bad. I liked the in-game instant service the best. Although it was pretty laggy when moving on the main platform and in the city. My normal ping is 10 to 50 in most games. Connection for move confirmation to slide my character was hugging around 600 ping. Some potato server stuff right there. Maybes it's a server default ping to keep everyone the same or something. I don't know.

I keep going back to try out the game some more and I keep geting more gold out of it. So apparently, beyond eating noobie nublet food, the only way to charge HP is at the inn. Which takes up to 10 minutes to charge you HP. This is by far the worst HP recovery system I have ever seen. You want players to sit in an empty room for 10 minutes before going back out? Oh my god. Haha! I guess you could try to craft a camp fire but since level 1 axes can't harvest level 1 wood, I can't gather any.

I've been trying to figure out a way to charge my HP without waiting 10 minutes at an inn. Turns out, I can just kill myself and get full HP. There's a 5% exp loss but it takes about 2 minutes to get that back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345416615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 10645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6935, 'last_played': 1599043789}
review:
This game is very fun and addictive! A classic DnD styled turn based strategy game that is just getting started and has lots of great visuals and content, and plays smoothly too. I love the cartoonish fantasy art style they've chosen. The community is very helpful and diverse, from level grinders, roleplayers, crafters, dungeon destroyers, and many more and room for nearly any play style you like; wether it's active diligence, casual fun, or anything in-between. There is currently no pvp, but clan based and potential other pvp funtions are in the works. The dev team is very active and do everything they can within their means to help and support the cummunity. Below I'll add some helpful links to look at as you're looking into this fantastic game. The game is not P2W, but there are convinence items and cosmetics that are great to have. They are not essential to be the best :) There are currently less than 10 things in the cash shop that can't be bought with in game currency (excluding cosmectics, but including xp boosts, an xp debt item, a storage bag [it is only 2 slots more than the highest available with ingame currency], the ability to have more than 4 characters, and the ability to have more than one "complex" profession on a character [i.e. cooking, weapon smithing, alchemy, etc.]). Many of said items can be bought through the market via ingame currency from players. 
Thanks for reading this review and looking forward to seeing you ingame!
IGN: Saharia

Stash Wiki (A little outdated, but good general info):
https://stash.gamepedia.com/Stash_Wiki

The Offical Stash Discord:
http://discord.gg/stashrpg

The Stash Forum:
http://forums.frogdice.com/forum.php

Hope all those links work (should be able to copy and paste them if not) and feel feel to message me ingame anytime! :)

There is a bit of a learning curve if you jump in blind, but there are some nice player written guides and plenty of people around to answer all the questions I had. author: {'steamid': '76561198006259620', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1516158065}
review:
Note:
As of the time of this edit, the developer has addressed most of the things i mentioned in this review and has replied below.  Please read their response before taking my review at face.  I have changed my score to positive as they have fixed what I thought made the game not worth playing.  I don't know if I'd personally be willing to invest time into the game just yet, but there are certainly people who would find it fun.

Old review:

This game has potential, but it's severely lacking in certain areas.  The game consists entirely of grind and tactical combat, and that is enjoyable for some people.  But, the process of doing both of these has certain things about them that makes them unenjoyable.

First of all, the game desparately needs a context sensitive click system when in combat.  When trying to do anything, you must first select the catagory of what you want to do, like move, skills, gather, ect. and then click on the grid to do it.  Almost every other with this sort of combat has the ability to do things automatically when you click on a space, like move to that space if the space is empty, gather if the space has a resource node on it, or do a basic attack if there's an enemy there.  Being able to chain these as well would be nice, like clicking on an enemy out of melee range, and the game moves your character into range and attacks. Having to select what you want to do every time gets tiresome fast.

Another thing the game needs to fix is the camera.  Outside of combat you cannot move the center of focus for the camera, which means that finding the right way to go is incredibly frustrating, as the dungeons are mostly mazes.  It's very easy to get lost and not know where the exit is, and since most tiles are the exact same texture and look, it's not like you can use your surroundings to figure it out.  The camera also likes to move behind things that don't turn invisible, meaning you have to constantly be fighting with it to see what's going on.

While these things may be nitpicky, since the game wants you to be grinding for a very long time, the struggle with just playing the base game becomes too much.  If these issues were addressed, it might be worth playing, but like other reviewers have said, there are other things lacking as well.  As of right now, the game isn't worth investing time into, but that could change.  The idea isn't horrible, so maybe with some polish it could have a niche following.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054512706', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 13008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8309, 'last_played': 1517284830}
review:
The game features an abundance of systems which create opportunities for diversity in game-play. It is completely f2p with optional purchases. We get the perfect blend between a board game and a MMORPG, here you will see characters standing on a peg base giving it a very unique feel.

Key features:
-	Real Free to Play
-	Old School
-	Turn based combat
-	Elaborate crafting system
-	Friendly community oriented game
-	Grind in a fun progressive way (I have played 60 hours in 3 days...)
-	Working economy with no staff interference required
-	Very customizable
-	Great music
-	Staff listens to players
-       Roleplay friendly
-	Specialized AI


Stash is not for everybody. This is a turn based tiled MMORPG with global dungeons, private dungeons and more. It is not intended to be easily mastered in every way and it brings back that feeling of challenge to it, where decisions you make have real outcomes on what you do and how you do it. I recommend giving it a try, it’s free and a small download.

Being an indie developer, graphics might look funny (and they actually are funny); yet Stash brings a lot of innovative systems to the MMORPG genre.

Game-play is a lot of fun, it can be a bit tedious at times because of how challenging the game has been tailored on contrary to about any other game out there where our attention is rapidly lost and we end up looking for another game within a week because of the greed vs benefit ratio the game has.

Stash brings back that social aspect of games, this is a game with a true community.

I have to say that the way monster AI works on Stash is exceptionally well done. They have types, races, roles, etc and each one of these characteristics add to the way they behave. This creates formidable combinations to fight against making it challenging, yet not impossible.

What to expect?

-	Slightly confusing at the beginning
-	Lots of documentation accessible in-game
-	Turn based combat
-	Addictive grinding
-	Crafting is important
-	Stash/Inventory space is limited yet freely expandable
-	Friendly community
-	Difficult first few levels
-	Couple minor bugs and UI issues that are being worked on
-	Placing ads on the in-game newspaper to sell valuable loot
-	Lots and lots of old school fun

I can't cover everything this game has to offer on a review, give it a try and experience it yourself!

I rate it 9.2/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198052496059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 55864, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10632, 'last_played': 1522730862}
review:
First thoughts: Fun. Addictive. Casual. Social. Crafting. Gathering.

This game is like a board game come to life. You have a "pawn" that moves around squares on the "board". You have a camp (house) to upgrade, furnish, craft, garden, etc. You go find & fight mobs for loot & materials in fun turn based mini-dungeons. These encounters are scattered randomly around the board & are color coded by difficulty, so you can make the fights as easy, or as difficult, as you desire. 

It has clans (guilds) and a social, talkative community that actually help each other out. If, like me, you miss that social atmosphere from games in your past, you'll happily find it again here. Its easy to solo encounters & just as easy to find others to party up with.

There are tons of different things to do to keep you busy: 
- fight mobs
- gather resources
- complete task
- craft
- farm plants/animals
- sell/buy at market
- upgrade camp, bags, stall, stash
- clan bonfire events
- random, friendly competitions for rewards

But...it still needs work.

Cons:
- No search in market
- No map
- No guidance/instructions provided for most items, making many things unclear as how to proceed
- Wiki very incomplete
- No directional marker. Easy to get turned around.
- No zoom inside larger dungeons


All in all, i'm really enjoying playing. This game is constantly evolving. Big things are in the works as we speak. We get to help shape the game and watch from the beginning as things unfold. The developer is in game and always around to offer advice and take input & suggestions. If you're looking for a fun, casual, busy game with an active community, this is totally the game for you. Highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060851100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1515572189}
review: I first saw Stash played on Crumps2's Twitch stream back when it was in testing phase and was rather intrigued by the game. I recently installed & played Stash. It's really easy to pick up (even without reading the help tips). While it does have some features that have become staples to MMOs since EverQuest, there are other features that are quite an interesting take. Combat, for instance is an obvious difference compared to the highly successful MMOs of EverQuest, Final Fantasy XIV & World of Warcraft. The GMs are quite welcoming and helpful, as well as visibly active in the game. And the developers are some nice, down-to-earth folks as well. If you're bored of your usual MMO fare, and/or close to burnout, this game is a good way to fill up that time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069149035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 19199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8838, 'last_played': 1556229879}
review: This game has an appealing combination of old school, nostalgia worthy RPG elements with a crafting and base development system that is very cathartic. I am astonished by the level of involvement the developers have with the entire player base. They're all so friendly, helpful, and eager to gobble up suggestions for improvements and/or new ideas.  I have found that the community as a whole is so friendly that its essentially a feature of the game that makes me want to keep coming back.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148124234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3906, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3906, 'last_played': 1515656774}
review: This game is great! In depth crafting, well thought out combat. Neat map and good system for loot. Love that player crafted gear is better than drops and the vendoring system is great. Awesome community, lots of fun and silliness but mostly mature players. Dev's are on line almost all the time, they and the community are super helpful. And I love that idiots or ragers seem to be dealt with quickly and well! Definately worth giving it some fair game time as it has more depth than what you think at the beginning, played for a couple of months and still more content we haven't touched yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031147240', 'num_games_owned': 58, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3978, 'last_played': 1515656688}
review: Great game! Been playing for months with friends and it is simple, yet satisfying. Combat is turn based which makes it very casual, but challenging. No quests means low end reading, but there is crafting and housing and mats gathering and selling on a closed market. One BIG plus is the community is awesome from the lead dev Snarlax to all the people in chat helping or discussing the game. I urge you to give it a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198804091056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1515557629}
review:
I'm a big fan of the grind, which Stash has to offer heaps of. It's a cute little game with great music, and a very helpful base of players who are always engaging in the game, as well as on the Discord chat.

And while I love grinding, I love the fact that my "Base Of Operations" is fully customizable. It just adds more depth to me and really gives me a purpose to the "grind"!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010924007', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1515459663}
review:
All though turn base is a novel change on things i would not recomend this game to MMO players unless they are in the 10 to 16 age range.
And even then this game needs a better guide than the "help" page. also tasks should at the very least say how to complete them. not just let you guess. When you need to look up the anwser on the games wiki and its not even there, on a starter task i might add. then you are not doing your job as dev.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075886447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1515334140}
review: This game is a great mmo, reminds me of an online dungeon and dragons aesthestically. I'd highly recommend it, it's easy to play and doesn't present any glitches or running errors.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179027831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7993, 'last_played': 1582733016}
review:
I LOVE this game...reminds me of D&D way back, there is room for improvement, but as is it is a great relaxing game.  The staff and players are friendly and very helpful.
This would be a great game for young teens and teens....

author: {'steamid': '76561198128136104', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1515154373}
review:
An MMO with a tabletop style gameplay experience is a fun idea. While Stash has some issues, it delivers on enough fronts to make the experience enjoyable. It’s obvious that the game is a little rough around the edges, but the art style and the music make it a pleasant experience.
The game is a little barebones, in that the content can get repetitive but the developers are still active and are adding new features. The combat system features some intriguing strategic elements, with flanking and surrounding allowing tactical choices. Sometimes, this doesn’t work as expected but it’s a fun system anyway.
There are little to no guides for the game and it is not shy of letting you grind. Everything from collecting resources for your base to getting new gear requires significant effort, as crafting items requires materials that drop as loot in dungeons. It’s a bit overwhelming at first but the community is really helpful and you can be up to speed in no time.
The game doesn’t really have a great story and the MMO open world feels a bit small. The developers have said that they will be adding new areas and story elements, but nothing can be said about that yet.
Character customization is not something that I expected to be good, but I found it very enjoyable and spent a decent amount of time tinkering with it.
Overall, I like the game’s premise and found it very fun. It seems like it is going to get even better so I would recommend it to anyone looking to try a new MMO.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004045603', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 4330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3080, 'last_played': 1515415436}
review:
Enjoying my time with this one... different enough to where it leaves me intrigued. Not a p2w thankfully... good community and what not, very helpful. Devs are active and willing to shell out advice when ya need it.

Although it seems basic plenty of stuff to do. Crafting will take a bit but no worries on that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101524009', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1514941855}
review:
After messing around for a bit I am quite impressed by what you have created. Sure it's a little rough around the edges, but the combat is straight forward. Progressing is clear and there are several things to do right off the bat. Most games like this have a pay wall right in your face after booting up, but here the payment options is kept quietly in the back ground. I have a few questions about the pricing options but overall it doesn't seem so bad.

1 thing I really found rather unique was the Base Of Opperations feature, the drop rate on items for it is quite high. The pricing on upgrades seems reasonable and it's not a wallet magnet which is pleasant change from popular mmos.

Overall I'd say this is a solid game that could use a bigger community to realize it's potential. Certainly better with friends anyways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106839108', 'num_games_owned': 105, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 64, 'last_played': 1514923176}
review:
Pros:
- The music is pretty good
- The fighting mechanics was a good thing to implement
- The art style is good
- You can create parties to go into dungeons with your friends
- (My favorite part) Character Customization is great

Cons:
- The game throws a lot at you as soon as you spawn in and it can become confusing very quickly
- Some of the camera angles can be a bit difficult such as when fighting enemies in a dungeon
- When moving there is no animation to the character
- The outside map seems a little bit bland

- OVERALL -
I believe this game has a good amount of potential and could become even better, therefore I think this game was good

author: {'steamid': '76561198303797507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1514731177}
review: Ne fonctionne pas, dommage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138083145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1514588474}
review:
If you are looking for a f2p RPG that won't break the bank with in-game microtransactions, then you should check this title out. 

At first, I was pleasantly surprised with the character customization, because I was able to choose whatever skin, eye and hair color I wanted. Also, there is a nice variety of races and classes for a free game. 

The gameplay is quite simple, the world is quite extense and turn based strategy MMOs have always been amongst my favorite types of games. 

I wish I could have tested it out on maximum graphic quality to judge them properly, but that was a technical issue on my side.

Overall, I would recommend this game to any person who is searching for a classic rpg gaming experience that doesn't ask for a lot of money from the player's side (unless you want the DLCs, which I haven't tried out yet!).

author: {'steamid': '76561198028932999', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1602952176}

author: {'steamid': '76561198799997473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1514650999}
review: Wanted to try something new over the holidays and found this surprise. Having a great time killing monsters and taking their stuff which is what i love best about rpgs. Really nice people in game and I'm hoping to find a clan to join. Really got lucky finding this game. I wouldn't mind more storage!!!! I guess I need to earn it so that's ok but I am a hoarder.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009713304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 183139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7011, 'last_played': 1532918230}
review: This is a great game. I love the grid combat system, its not for people who like fast combat but if you like to be strategic then give this game a try. You start with a small camp and can eventually grow it into a house. There is plenty of crafting. In fact crafted items are almost always better than dropped items.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979545810', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 671, 'last_played': 1514072084}
review:
The idea seems sound, but the rewards for the time needed to grind are not there.  I found the game quite boring and unrewarding.  The choice of difficulty settings is a nice touch, but anything less than +2 is just so unrewarding.  I found this game fun in a group, but groups are an ultra rare solution.  The community seems nice, but a game is more than just a good community when its so small the opportunities also get smaller.  Movement is not that smooth due to this block to block feature; although click to travel can be.  Equipping gear does sometimes change the look of your charaacter, but the gear is all kind of plain.  Could they turn this around?  Yes, any game can, but will they?  In the history of video games such turn-arounds have happened, but its requires such a radical change that they most likely will not want to bother.  So this game for me is the type of game where I would always be asking myself ...why didn't they do this or that and why do they have it that way which is so unoptimized.

This game would be good for an early access or a beta, but as a complete game, very limited and in my opinion no real replay value.

I do like the idea of this game and its like a moveable tabletop game just like it says.  So I will give it a rating of 5.5/10, but recommending it is something I cannot do in its current state.  

RATING: 5.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198074148615', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 93684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21659, 'last_played': 1524878237}
review: I'll admit I haven't written many reviews even with all the titles I've bought on steam but I feel I must on this one.As you can tell I have a few hours in on this game and I can tell you its quite different from alot of the mmorpgs i've played and I have tried hundreds. I'm not a big fan of turn based combat but it very hard to find a good crafting game where your not hiding around every tree trying not to get killed by every griefer in the world just trying to get enough mats to build a house. This game is very casual with a great staff and people that are willing to listen to input.It is not P2W like alot of the games out there and most important stuff can be bought in the cash shop with in game currency as long as your willing to save up for it.I am in no way affiliated with the makers of this game but just enjoy a casual relaxing game with very nice and willing to help player base don't be afraid to give it a chance it might seem quite outdated graphics wise but it hooks you with its combat and crafting systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198380380314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 777, 'playtime_forever': 1267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1517224292}
review: На один раз, не тратьте время.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077906680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1513449856}
review:
Now I might be missing something important, but this feels like a tiny fragment of a half-decent game. Missing something important should be forgiveable here, as the wiki is a joke with most pages either being 'stub' or a couple of sentences pasted from the in-game description.

So for the first ~2.5 hours, I'm totally and utterly lost, and without the help of other players in the chat I'd still be. There's some basic in-game guides for certain aspects, but plenty of stuff isn't covered and this is only for the very beginning.

First thing that happens is I go into an encounter with a decrepit gargantupine. Turns out it meant 2 porcupines and a bat, all level 3 which totally wreck me as I'm level 1.

I die, I respawn, and I now fight something easier.

Level 1 bats. Where the porcupines were doing like 30 damage, this guys do about 3-4. I try to spam my firebolt spell, but, turns out you have to wait a turn. And it does basically the same damage as swinging my staff like a club. It turns out this is how you're meant to fight, just spamming melee attacks every turn. But aha, there's strategy! If multiple teammates are adjacent to an enemy they get [i]surrounded[/i], and there's similar stuff for being [i]flanked[/i] and [i]pinned[/i]. Great! Except every combatant moves about 4 squares at a time and can escape basically any bad situation. This also means the [i]surrounded[/i] thing is just a flat debuff to your damage in basically every solo battle as you are always outnumbered and you can't out-run them.

I later find out (of course I have to look at the wiki) that I should learn a profession. [i][b][u]A[/u][/b][/i] profession, as you have to pay to learn another. I choose enchanter as this seems like a good way to power up my armour. Speaking of armour, I have a look at some stalls. (Did I mention that there is apparently no central auction house? You either right-click people to trade with them (good luck with that) or use people's 'stalls' of which you get a random-ish selection, refined into 3-5 broad categories. No search function. No easy price comparison. Yuk.)

The armour and weapons I come across look... familiar. I have a look at the wiki to see what there is and I see a grand total of 25 things. Now there may be more, but I've never seen any evidence of it. And that's not 25 options per slot, that's 25 [b]TOTAL[/b]. ie [i]one set per class[/i]. Compare that to another MMO I played (which I had hoped this would be an improvement on). Something like 1000 different bits of gear, just based on the number of wiki pages. And some have unique abilities. I get that that was by a much larger dev team, and making lots of 3D models takes a lot of time, but seriously. Besides, a two-person dev team that was Cube World gave us plenty of variety. A third MMO I played had about 200, and those had very detailed models. We don't even need different skins for them or even inventory icons (speaking of which, there are only a few and lots of different items share the same icon), but [i]one set per class[/i]. I just can't get over how ridiculous that is.

You can of course get different qualities and enchantment slots, but there are no special abilities. It does come in different levels, but that's just an extra bit of grind attached to every few levels you want to go up. Speaking of grind:

AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

'nuff said. Actually, let me say a little bit more. The max level is 30. According to the leaderboards, 8 people have reached this point. None in my class. Really inspiring, isn't it? The grind amounts to fighting encounters or going into dungeons (glorified encounter-fests), gathering the shitty materials and worthless gear and selling it to vendors (at terrible prices) or to players (of which there are so few, and no-one wants to buy your junk). Throughout your travels you can discover a vast array of adversaries, amounting to a jaw-dropping... 12 different types. There are at least bosses as well, 5 different ones according to the wiki. 2 of which have no link and I suspect don't actually exist in-game. In order to at least give this game a fair review I gave one of them a go, first solo (which amounted to playing hide-and-seek around a rock with a boss who has a self-healing spell that heals about 40% more damage than I can deal in the same amount of time) and then with a partner (a much better experience, if she had started on full health I think we would have won). In the other MMO I mentioned, there are hundreds of unique monsters and probably 70+ unique bosses [i]all with their own unique attacks and mechanics[/i]. Here bosses are just tanky monsters with a healing spell. As for variety in attacks, to my knowledge all monsters have one melee attack and one ranged attack. Some have decent animations at least, but the variety is totally superficial.

That brings me on to the playerbase. Now, contrary to what I've heard from the other negative reviews, the people I've met in chat have been helpful and friendly. Slight problem. There's only a few of them. In this few hours I've racked up the most deaths on the leaderboard this week (11) and according to Steam Charts there's a staggering 22.5 people online on average.

I never really tried out the base building properly, since the material grind is unreal. Each upgrade needs something like 3-10 building materials (of which there are about 6 types so there's always one that you just can't find), and where do you get those? From a DIY store in the main town (more about that later)? Nope, you get them from killing monsters, and it's a pretty uncommon drop so get grinding. After a fair bit of said grinding I finally find a bloody stupid wooden plank and upgrade my stash, which at this point is bursting at the seams with only 20 slots. Huzzah! I can store more stuff now! The storage has been upgraded to... 21 slots. Ah. Next I have to do about double the grind to even be able to place my enchanting crafting thing, but I've long since given up hope.

Finally, the map. Here's a quote from the wiki:


[i]Primordiax is the massive open world and realm in which Stash takes place.[/i]

Funny isn't it? Stash has the smallest world of any game I've ever seen. Look at my playtime: I've walked all the way along its Western edge. In about 5 minutes. And I forgot to mention how agonisingly slow walking is in this game, so yeah. I mentioned the 'main town' earlier. Turns out it's the only town, as far as I am aware. Look at the wiki: the [i]Locations[/i] category has 2 pages:
Askagard
Dungeons
Funnier still, this is the same page that I got the quote above from.

But how could I be so unsure of whether there are other towns? Because there's no map of course! I can only assume that the impassable barriers (forests that you can't step into, a mysterious ghostly red wall, no map loading beyond a certain point, 3m tall mountains you can't climb and the many streams (seriously, they look like they must be at least 6 inches deep, don't go in them or you might drown)).

I can see why they say this is like a tabletop game: they've cleverly managed to fit all of the fuck all content into a 'massive open world' that fits on your tabletop. Brilliant, right?

----------------

So, I've rambled a lot, but my point should be clear. This has something like 10% of the content of an actual playable game, and the gaping hole that is left is filled by extreme grind. Much of the stuff that is boasted about in the trailer and elsewhere is just standard fare for an MMO (or at least certainly isn't unique to Stash), except done in a unique way (unique as in no-one else would dream of making something so grindy and unfinished). The only bits that do actually stand out (the nice graphical look and the turn-based combat) are not good enough to make this an actual game, with the turn-based combat being totally shallow and dull.

I'll give it

3/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198088607678', 'num_games_owned': 847, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 16345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8232, 'last_played': 1514922740}
